title: Find the Location of the Median
text: To find the median of a data set, we want to first determine the location of the median. Remember the formula for that data point is $$\frac{n+1}{2}$$ where n represents the total number of data points in the set.

title: Determining Location of the Median
text: What is the location of the median? What is $$\frac{n+1}{2}$$?

title: Finding the 33rd Data Value
text: What is the median? In other words, what is the 33rd data point?

title: Determining Where the 33rd Data Point Is
text: To determing where the 33rd data point is at, we know that the frequency of selling 3 cars is 14, the frequency of selling 4 cars is 19, and the frequency of selling 5 cars is 12. To find the 33rd data point, add up the frequencies until you get to 33 and that number of cars will be the median value.

title: Subset to Determining Location of 33rd Data Point
text: What is the total frequency of people who have sold 3 cars (the minimum)?

title: Subset to Determining Location of 33rd Data Point
text: What is the total frequency of people who have sold 3 or 4 cars? Add up the frequencies.

title: Subset to Determining Location of 33rd Data Point
text: Is 33, the total frequency of selling 3 or 4 cars, greater than or equal to 33, the desired location of the median?

title: Final Step to Determining 33rd Data Point
text: If 14 was the total frequency of selling 3 cars and 33 was the total frequency of selling 3 or 4 cars, is the 33rd data point (the median value) selling 3 cars or 4 cars?
